text1: Providing healthcare as a human right ensures citizens' access to life and obligates the state to provide it to all.
text2: Health care as a a human right impacts the people's ability to access other fundamental rights such as the right to freedom and liberty.

text1: Providing healthcare as a human right ensures citizens' access to life and obligates the state to provide it to all.
text2: It is not necessary for the state to provide health care as people can access it themselves.

text1: Universal healthcare, as provided by the state, protects everyone's right to life.
text2: Universal healthcare is not feasible.

text1: Universal healthcare, as provided by the state, protects everyone's right to life.
text2: Universal healthcare, as a human right, is counterproductive if it cannot be fully provided by the government.

text1: Universal healthcare, as provided by the state, protects everyone's right to life.
text2: Universally available preventive health care, as opposed to complete universal health care, can effectively fulfill a state's duty to protect a person's right to life.

text1: Universal healthcare can reduce the spread of communicable diseases.
text2: Many policies, such as lock-downs, can also reduce the spread of communicable diseases.

text1: For those suffering from disease, health care is necessary to ensure survival.
text2: If disease has been contracted due to personal negligence, it is unfair for the government to fund recovery at the cost of potentially beneficial programs for those citizens who led healthier lives.

text1: This assumes that the sick (or the poor, in your analogy) are not at fault for their condition. That is not always the case.
text2: Universal healthcare requires everyone to contribute to the system, which some consider unfair because it makes the sick pay for the sick.

text1: Many countries already do provide healthcare that improves wellbeing rather than just emergency treatment.
text2: Emergency life-sustaining treatment may be feasible, but a broad definition that encompasses all things improving well-being would be impractical.

text1: Many other human rights have semi-vague quantifications, and still function well. The specifics can be left to each government.
text2: It is difficult to quantify the extent to which health care is a right, which makes the idea of universal health care impractical.

text1: Many other human rights have semi-vague quantifications, and still function well. The specifics can be left to each government.
text2: A right cannot be vague or it is meaningless.

text1: Many other human rights have semi-vague quantifications, and still function well. The specifics can be left to each government.
text2: This argument is fallacious as it is predicated on other human rights being accepted as human rights.

text1: Low quality healthcare is better than none.
text2: It is difficult to quantify the extent to which health care is a right, which makes the idea of universal health care impractical.

text1: Low quality healthcare is better than none.
text2: Low quality medical interventions can be dangerous for the patient.

text1: The World Health organisation (WHO) has released a report which maps the ways that all countries can sustainably achieve universal healthcare.
text2: Universal healthcare is not feasible.

text1: The World Health organisation (WHO) has released a report which maps the ways that all countries can sustainably achieve universal healthcare.
text2: This report's recommendations for sustainability are as follows: 1) Increase the efficiency of revenue collection 2) Reprioritize government budgets 3) Innovative financing 4) Development assistance for health. In short: raise taxes, spend more on healthcare, raise more money, and get money from other nations. Hardly "innovative".

text1: A universal healthcare system can exist in numerous forms.
text2: Universal healthcare is not feasible.

text1: A universal healthcare system can exist in numerous forms.
text2: Universal health care, in any form, necessitates substantial government spending, which is typically financed through increased taxation.

text1: Advancements in technology and medicine makes it feasible to provide health care to all.
text2: Universal healthcare is not feasible.

text1: Advancements in technology and medicine makes it feasible to provide health care to all.
text2: The advanced technology has only served to increase the cost, not lessen it.

text1: A good deal of modern medical costs for the hospitals is administration needed to handle payments from virtually limitless insurance companies.
text2: The advanced technology has only served to increase the cost, not lessen it.

text1: Private healthcare is an option in countries with public healthcare systems for those who prefer not to wait.
text2: Universal healthcare does not provide equal access; long wait times for treatment are common, as seen in Canada, and Britain.

text1: Many countries, both rich and poor, already provide universal healthcare, demonstrating that it is an achievable standard to require and not an impossible one.
text2: Universal healthcare, as a human right, is counterproductive if it cannot be fully provided by the government.

text1: Even with preventative care, some conditions may go undetected or be misdiagnosed until it is too late for effective treatment.
text2: Universally available preventive health care, as opposed to complete universal health care, can effectively fulfill a state's duty to protect a person's right to life.

text1: Preventative care requires regular checkups and monitoring, which may not be accessible in a world without complete universal health care.
text2: Universally available preventive health care, as opposed to complete universal health care, can effectively fulfill a state's duty to protect a person's right to life.

text1: The lack of financial consequences does not equate to the absence of physical repercussions.
text2: Free healthcare may lead to neglect of personal health due to lack of financial consequences, resulting in a burden on the government funding the care.

text1: No one would purposely hurt themselves because they could get healthcare for free.
text2: Free healthcare may lead to neglect of personal health due to lack of financial consequences, resulting in a burden on the government funding the care.

text1: Most people are naturally deterred from engaging in unhealthy or risky behavior due to a fear of injury or death.
text2: If treated as a civil right, people won't take responsibility for unhealthy behaviors.

text1: Most people are naturally deterred from engaging in unhealthy or risky behavior due to a fear of injury or death.
text2: A lack of free health care may enhance a person's natural aversion to risky behavior.

text1: Countries can create incentives that nudge people towards better life choices.
text2: If treated as a civil right, people won't take responsibility for unhealthy behaviors.

text1: Countries can create incentives that nudge people towards better life choices.
text2: The goal to restrict people from engaging in any behavior that might jeopardize their health is unrealistic.

text1: If societies understand health as a human right it creates a legal obligation on states to ensure access to timely, acceptable, and affordable health care of appropriate quality.
text2: Life is a right, but individuals are responsible for taking care of it, obligating other to do so violates their freedom.

text1: Human rights are inherent and cannot be revoked because they might "impact other people".
text2: Health care as a a human right impacts the people's ability to access other fundamental rights such as the right to freedom and liberty.

text1: A lack of health care coerces people into making choices that compromise their freedom and liberty.
text2: Health care as a a human right impacts the people's ability to access other fundamental rights such as the right to freedom and liberty.

text1: A lack of health care coerces people into making choices that compromise their freedom and liberty.
text2: Universal health care by default limits a person's financial freedom, since they cannot opt out of the program and spend their tax contribution elsewhere.

text1: Poorer citizens may be forced to take up debt in order to pay for excessive medical bills.
text2: People can access debt settlement programs in order to get out of debt.

text1: Corporations are incentivized by profits, and as such, they have no obligation to provide healthcare free of charge.
text2: Health care can be made available without government provision, as businesses can provide it through markets.

text1: When healthcare is provided by the private sector, it can still be a human right, it would just be enforced by government regulations.
text2: Health care can be made available without government provision, as businesses can provide it through markets.

text1: It is the duty of the state to protect vulnerable citizens.
text2: It is not necessary for the state to provide health care as people can access it themselves.

text1: It is the duty of the state to protect vulnerable citizens.
text2: The state can provide healthcare only to vulnerable citizens without declaring it a human right across the board.

text1: Denying the right to health care disproportionately discriminates against aged, sick, disabled, and poor citizens.
text2: Just because an action causes more harm to one group than another doesn't make it discriminatory.​

text1: Denying the right to health care disproportionately discriminates against aged, sick, disabled, and poor citizens.
text2: State has a duty to protect citizens, but open-ended healthcare commitment may burden future citizens paying for an aging population's care.

text1: Denying healthcare to the poor is ethically wrong.
text2: Money is not as consequential to the absence of suffering as medical and technological advancements are. Rich people of the past had less access to effective care than poor people today do.

text1: Denying healthcare to the poor is ethically wrong.
text2: Resources are limited. It is impossible to provide a standard of care for everyone that is equivalent to what wealthy people can afford.

text1: Denying healthcare to the poor is ethically wrong.
text2: Low wages and the absence of employer health insurance programs have led to the poor's inability to access healthcare, not a lack of government provision.

text1: More money can fund the further expansion of necessary medical and technological advancements.
text2: Money is not as consequential to the absence of suffering as medical and technological advancements are. Rich people of the past had less access to effective care than poor people today do.

text1: We need human rights for protection when our legal rights are violated by the state, and to encourage justice and fairness within our societies. Making healthcare a human right would mean that citizens have the ability to challenge their state, if that state fails to fulfil their rights.
text2: The state can provide healthcare only to vulnerable citizens without declaring it a human right across the board.

text1: Lack of healthcare can lead to needless suffering for everyone, and the state has a duty to protect all citizens.
text2: The state can provide healthcare only to vulnerable citizens without declaring it a human right across the board.

text1: Health care is necessary for people to live good and fulfilling lives.
text2: Not everything that gives people more fulfilling lives is necessarily a right.

text1: Health care is necessary for people to live good and fulfilling lives.
text2: Healthcare may be helpful or necessary at times, but its impact on one's ability to lead a fulfilling life can vary.

text1: Poor health can cause suffering and reduce one's potential in life.
text2: A fulfilling life requires exercise, healthy eating, social connections, and a sense of purpose; it however cannot be said that it is a human right.

text1: Poor health can cause suffering and reduce one's potential in life.
text2: Poor health does not necessarily diminish one's potential in life, and healthcare may not always be essential for a long life

text1: A healthy body is necessary for productivity and work, making health care a basic precondition to a good and fulfilling life.
text2: Examples of individuals like Stephen Hawking and Helen Keller demonstrate that one's level of physical ability does not necessarily limit their ability to participate in society.

text1: Poor health and injuries can affect individuals through no fault of their own.
text2: ER patients receive treatment regardless of their ability to pay upfront; they are then responsible for paying their debt later.

text1: Poor health and injuries can affect individuals through no fault of their own.
text2: Poor health and injuries are inherent to living, and not caused by others, thus no one is obliged to provide treatment or remedy.

text1: Disease is a weakness that we all share. Therefore we should pool our resources and band together.
text2: Human psychology is full of weaknesses that lead to behaviors contrary to our health and well-being. Taking collective action to address the behavioral shortcomings of individuals is problematic, but probably necessary if we accept that premise that instances of weakness demand societal intervention.

text1: Disease is a weakness that we all share. Therefore we should pool our resources and band together.
text2: Healthier people should not have to pay for the unhealthy choices of those who do not care for themselves. This is taxation of health and subsidy of illness.

text1: Disease is a weakness that we all share. Therefore we should pool our resources and band together.
text2: "Should" does not equal "Must". A goal is not the same as a demand. Even in the Communist Manifesto we have the concept of "ability". That applies to society as well as the individual. As our society becomes wealthier, we may become more generous, but generosity is not an obligation, and we often forget the difference.

text1: Heart disease, cancer, thyroid disease, and depression are all well-known chronic illnesses that are not the fault of the individual.
text2: Common illnesses, such as heart disease and diabetes, can result from personal decisions; treating self-inflicted damage shouldn't be considered a right.

text1: Lower-income individuals are marginalized and unable to pay for healthcare, which can lead to inability to pay for necessary treatments, resulting in long-term debt.
text2: ER patients receive treatment regardless of their ability to pay upfront; they are then responsible for paying their debt later.

text1: ERs are inadequate for addressing the majority of healthcare problems, such as lifelong conditions like diabetes which require continuous management.
text2: ER patients receive treatment regardless of their ability to pay upfront; they are then responsible for paying their debt later.

text1: Poor health and injuries can result from external factors, such as car crashes caused by others or employers' inadequate health and safety measures.
text2: Poor health and injuries are inherent to living, and not caused by others, thus no one is obliged to provide treatment or remedy.

text1: Population-wide diseases, such as STDs, are the responsibility of the entire population, thus necessitating collective remedial actions.
text2: Poor health and injuries are inherent to living, and not caused by others, thus no one is obliged to provide treatment or remedy.

text1: Society bears responsibility for repairing the damage caused by natural disasters, and so it should be responsible for providing healthcare for illnesses, whether natural or otherwise.
text2: Poor health and injuries are inherent to living, and not caused by others, thus no one is obliged to provide treatment or remedy.

text1: Health of individuals living in a society contributes to the greater good of the community.
text2: Forcing people to pay for healthcare through the state, via taxes or other means, can have negative consequences for the community.

text1: Health of individuals living in a society contributes to the greater good of the community.
text2: Paying for the unhealthy or elderly yields no positive benefits for the payer.

text1: Health of individuals living in a society contributes to the greater good of the community.
text2: A dysfunctional government can pose a significant threat when they have jurisdiction over the availability and accessibility of medical services.

text1: Vaccination reduces disease spread and can free up resources for other purposes, promoting prosperity.
text2: Vaccines do not provide 100% protection against diseases and may not be effective for everyone.

text1: Vaccination reduces disease spread and can free up resources for other purposes, promoting prosperity.
text2: Vaccines can have side effects, and some people may have adverse reactions to them.

text1: Vaccination reduces disease spread and can free up resources for other purposes, promoting prosperity.
text2: Vaccinating the population is not the same as providing health care to the entire population.

text1: Increased rates vaccination can achieve herd immunity within a population, leading to a healthier society.
text2: Herd immunity contradicts the concept of human rights since it obligates individuals to get vaccinated, which is contrary to the freedom that is inherent in human rights.

text1: Vaccines are incredibly cost efficient, and likely even profitable for the taxpayer.
text2: Manufacturing vaccines can be incredibly expensive, which can result in a high end price of vaccines.

text1: The government's commitment to vaccinating everyone is a fundamental acknowledgement of its responsibility for the overall health of the community.
text2: Vaccinating the population is not the same as providing health care to the entire population.

text1: Everyone using the same service, including the wealthy, creates a natural incentive to improve the service.
text2: State-enforced healthcare creates a monopoly, without competition; even if the service is poor, individuals are still required to pay for it, leaving them with little recourse for change.

text1: Government initiatives funded by taxpayers, although unpopular, follow the democratic process, similar to other taxes.
text2: Being forced to fund initiatives that oppose one's morals can decrease government popularity.

text1: Government initiatives funded by taxpayers, although unpopular, follow the democratic process, similar to other taxes.
text2: The government's popularity also declines when it taxes its population for other unpopular initiatives, such as war.

text1: Taxes enable governments to fund public goods and services, such as infrastructure, education, healthcare, and social welfare programs, that benefit society as a whole.
text2: Forcing people to pay for healthcare through the state, via taxes or other means, can have negative consequences for the community.

text1: Taxes help ensure that everyone contributes to society in a fair and equitable way, and that individuals and businesses pay their fair share.
text2: Forcing people to pay for healthcare through the state, via taxes or other means, can have negative consequences for the community.

text1: Those people are still benefited later if they end up with health conditions that require a great deal of expensive medical care.
text2: Paying for the unhealthy or elderly yields no positive benefits for the payer.

text1: Healthcare is not only about treatment; it also involves prevention. Everyone can benefit from prevention.
text2: Paying for the unhealthy or elderly yields no positive benefits for the payer.

text1: A government cannot successfully fund an exclusionary healthcare system since it requires everyone to contribute in terms of taxes.
text2: A dysfunctional government can pose a significant threat when they have jurisdiction over the availability and accessibility of medical services.

text1: Reproductive Rights can be seen as a class of rights that argue for a person's access to sexual wellness for a healthier life.
text2: Sex is often necessary for a good and fulfilling life, as well as for the survival of the human race, but it is not considered a human right.

text1: Reproductive Rights can be seen as a class of rights that argue for a person's access to sexual wellness for a healthier life.
text2: It is a mischaracterization to suggest that reproductive rights expand to include a 'right to have sex.'

text1: Sex is essential for the survival and growth of the human race.
text2: Sex is often necessary for a good and fulfilling life, as well as for the survival of the human race, but it is not considered a human right.

text1: Sex is essential for the survival and growth of the human race.
text2: Whilst sex may be necessary for the survival of the human species, it is not necessary for individual survival.

text1: Most things that make a fulfilling life are not necessities, however things that facilitate survival are essential for a fulfilled life.
text2: Not everything that gives people more fulfilling lives is necessarily a right.

text1: Most things that make a fulfilling life are not necessities, however things that facilitate survival are essential for a fulfilled life.
text2: Under this definition, healthcare would only be a right in the event of curable, fatal diseases.

text1: Relatively few people choose suicide over medical treatment, for a "comfortable but shorter life" when ill.
text2: Health care may extend life, but not everyone acquires value from a long life.

text1: Access to healthcare can prevent or treat illnesses and injuries, which can help people to live longer, healthier lives.
text2: Healthcare may be helpful or necessary at times, but its impact on one's ability to lead a fulfilling life can vary.

text1: Access to healthcare can prevent or treat illnesses and injuries, which can help people to live longer, healthier lives.
text2: A longer, but financially poor, life may be unfulfilling.

text1: The idea that rights cannot be provided at another's expense can be seen as overly individualistic and neglectful of the broader societal benefits that can come from ensuring that everyone's rights are fulfilled.
text2: Rights are inherent to a person and not something to be provided at another's expense.

text1: Medical conditions can interfere with a person’s ability to access all other human rights. If the poor are denied healthcare for lack of money, they are being denied other human rights for lack of money. That goes against the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
text2: Rights are inherent to a person and not something to be provided at another's expense.

text1: Rights are determined by society, and individuals are not born with inherent rights.
text2: An inherent right is innate and exists naturally, independent of laws or society, and healthcare does not fit this definition.

text1: Rights are determined by society, and individuals are not born with inherent rights.
text2: Although one's place of birth and the actions of others can impact the degree to which their rights are respected, everyone possesses inherent and inalienable human rights.

text1: Rights are determined by society, and individuals are not born with inherent rights.
text2: A right can only be a natural right, best described as self-evident in the U.S. Declaration of Independence: "They are endowed by their creator with certain unalienable right."

text1: There is no such thing as a natural right. The very theory of natural rights is self-evidently the philosophical work of humans.
text2: Although one's place of birth and the actions of others can impact the degree to which their rights are respected, everyone possesses inherent and inalienable human rights.

text1: Health care systems do not suffer from a lack of physicians, but from an uneven distribution of physicians.
text2: There is an insufficient number of health care professionals working an insufficient number of man-hours to provide the level of care desired by universal healthcare advocates.

text1: Allocating finite resources to have the most positive impact reflects the belief that improving the overall population's health is a priority, similar to the belief that all individuals deserve equal access to health improvements.
text2: Fiercely contested components (e.g. organ donations) should be offered in terms of clinical suitability and likelihood of improvement, not equally.

text1: Advances in medical technology and research are constantly expanding the range of available medical treatments and inputs.
text2: Medical inputs necessary for a person's treatment are often limited in supply.

text1: Government investments in healthcare infrastructure and research can increase the availability of medical inputs over time.
text2: Medical inputs necessary for a person's treatment are often limited in supply.

text1: "Human right" doesn't mean equal application. It just means guaranteed opportunity for.
text2: Health care is a finite resource, and therefore cannot be inherent to each person.

text1: "Human right" doesn't mean equal application. It just means guaranteed opportunity for.
text2: This suggests that there isn't a right to health care, merely a right to pursue health care.

text1: Various resources, while being finite, are considered to be human rights.
text2: Health care is a finite resource, and therefore cannot be inherent to each person.

text1: Various resources, while being finite, are considered to be human rights.
text2: Health care is unique because it is much more expensive than any other necessary good like food or water. It is also not readily available from nature.

text1: Various resources, while being finite, are considered to be human rights.
text2: This claim proves the underlying lack of feasibility of proscribing positive rights to a good or service. Availability absolutely dictates access: if it's not there you can't have it.

text1: Food and shelter are finite resources, but generally accepted as basic human rights.
text2: Food and shelter is both essential to life and not provided by government, and yet almost nobody freezes or starves to death in the western world simply for want of food or shelter.

text1: Water, a finite resource, is defined by the UN as a human right.
text2: Health care does not occur naturally. If water comes through a pipe or in a bottle you still pay for it.

text1: Water, a finite resource, is defined by the UN as a human right.
text2: It is a lot easier to provide someone with clean water than with quality health care, so this is not a good comparison.

text1: Water is a human right whether it is found naturally, paid for by the bottle, or delivered by pipe.
text2: Health care does not occur naturally. If water comes through a pipe or in a bottle you still pay for it.

text1: Cost should not decide what is a right, but only cause a limit to the extent a right can be upheld.
text2: Health care is unique because it is much more expensive than any other necessary good like food or water. It is also not readily available from nature.

text1: Health care, while not an inherent right, but can be considered an economic, social, and cultural right, or a positive right.
text2: Health care cannot be termed as an inalienable, and inherent right.

text1: Health care, while not an inherent right, but can be considered an economic, social, and cultural right, or a positive right.
text2: The UN argues that the enjoyment of all human rights is interlinked so categories of rights such as “civil and political rights” or “economic, social and cultural rights” make little sense.

text1: Health care, while not an inherent right, but can be considered an economic, social, and cultural right, or a positive right.
text2: The U.S. Constitution does not provide for "Positive Rights" such as the right to health care.

text1: Justice, Equality, and Freedom of speech are beneficial for humanity even while not echoed in nature.
text2: Equality among humans is echoed in nature, hierarchy is a social construct.

text1: Justice, Equality, and Freedom of speech are beneficial for humanity even while not echoed in nature.
text2: Justice is a product of the supposed natural right to self defense and the right to property.

text1: Justice, Equality, and Freedom of speech are beneficial for humanity even while not echoed in nature.
text2: Freedom of speech is a derivative of the supposed natural right to freewill.

text1: Health care, as a human right, can be argued to be similarly interlinked to other fundamental human rights, such as the right to life.
text2: The UN argues that the enjoyment of all human rights is interlinked so categories of rights such as “civil and political rights” or “economic, social and cultural rights” make little sense.

text1: If human rights are only considered valid as formal legal rights, it undermines the universality of these principles due to the contingent historical and political nature of legal norms.
text2: The U.S. Constitution does not provide for "Positive Rights" such as the right to health care.

text1: If human rights are only considered valid as formal legal rights, it undermines the universality of these principles due to the contingent historical and political nature of legal norms.
text2: If a right isn't codified as formal legal right, there is no use-value to the right.

text1: There is an international consensus that health care is a human right.
text2: Health care cannot be termed as an inalienable, and inherent right.

text1: There is an international consensus that health care is a human right.
text2: A right is what is owed or allowed to people by their society. Nothing can be a right in general, but only within a particular context or society.

text1: The International Bill of Human Rights includes health care as a human right.
text2: Rights are determined by society and subject to what is feasible. If something cannot be provided, it cannot be considered a right in that society.

text1: The International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights also declares health care as an essential right, that must be accessible to all.
text2: Twenty four countries and four non-UN members have not ratified the treaty.

text1: The USA is an outlier as it refuses to ratify many otherwise-globally-accepted treaties such as the Conventaion against Torture, the Arms Trade Treaty, Convention on the Rights of the Child, Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, and even the treaty on treaties.
text2: The USA, a major world power, has not ratified the treaty.

text1: The USA recognizes parts of some non-ratified treaties as customary international law and binding upon them as such.
text2: Twenty four countries and four non-UN members have not ratified the treaty.

text1: In 1948, the UN adopted the Universal Human Rights Declaration. Article 25 (p. 52) states: "Everyone has the right to a standard of living adequate for the health and well-being of himself and of his family, including food, clothing, housing and medical care and necessary social services."
text2: Medical care is different from health care; treatment for a life-threatening affliction is not the same as annual check-ups.

text1: Healthcare is sometimes defined as "the organized provision of medical care to individuals or a community". This suggests there is little difference between the terms, as health care just refers to the provision of medical care.
text2: Medical care is different from health care; treatment for a life-threatening affliction is not the same as annual check-ups.

text1: Lack of food availability does not nullify the right to food, just as depletion of medical resources does not negate the right to treatment. Both are essential for survival and wellbeing, and should be replenished when possible.
text2: Rights are determined by society and subject to what is feasible. If something cannot be provided, it cannot be considered a right in that society.

text1: Just because healthcare is not possible to provide, doesn't mean it's not a human right; human rights are violated all the time, but that doesn't make them any less human rights.
text2: Human rights don't exist, but only particular and providable rights in each society - i.e., in a society where healthcare is providable, it will be a right.

text1: Human rights are often defined as inalienable, fundamental rights inherent to all human beings "regardless of their nation". Therefore, the overarching principle cannot be bound by location or type of society.
text2: Human rights don't exist, but only particular and providable rights in each society - i.e., in a society where healthcare is providable, it will be a right.

text1: Rights are inherent to human beings and not dependent on geography, culture, or time. Variations in rights across societies would imply a variable value of human life, which is discriminatory.
text2: A right is what is owed or allowed to people by their society. Nothing can be a right in general, but only within a particular context or society.

text1: Rights are inherent to human beings and not dependent on geography, culture, or time. Variations in rights across societies would imply a variable value of human life, which is discriminatory.
text2: Different societies and cultures have different values and beliefs, which can lead to different interpretations of what rights are and what they entail.

text1: You don't have a right to another's labor.
text2: Health care does not fit within the confines of what defines a human right.

text1: You don't have a right to another's labor.
text2: Several other human rights rely on the labor of others, and the resources of the state, to be upheld.

text1: No individual may compel another individual to provide a service to them; universal health care depends on the state compelling healthcare professionals to provide their service.
text2: Doctors can opt to work in the private sector, as opposed to, working for the state.

text1: No individual may compel another individual to provide a service to them; universal health care depends on the state compelling healthcare professionals to provide their service.
text2: Many governments require their citizens to perform mandatory labor in specific circumstances for the benefit of society.

text1: Being fairly compensated for the provision of your labor is a human right, and it conflicts with the declaration of health care as a right.
text2: Many accepted Human rights have conflicts between them.  In a developed nation, the Procedural Right to getting paid could co-exist with the Substantive right to healthcare.

text1: Being fairly compensated for the provision of your labor is a human right, and it conflicts with the declaration of health care as a right.
text2: Health care professional working in the public sector are fairly compensated for their labor.

text1: Being fairly compensated for the provision of your labor is a human right, and it conflicts with the declaration of health care as a right.
text2: Citizens have the free choice to not enter a paid-contractual relationship with the state as their employer.

text1: Mandatory labor can perpetuate systems of inequality and injustice, particularly if certain groups are disproportionately targeted or affected.
text2: Many governments require their citizens to perform mandatory labor in specific circumstances for the benefit of society.

text1: Mandatory labor is a form of exploitation and violates individuals' rights to freedom and autonomy.
text2: Many governments require their citizens to perform mandatory labor in specific circumstances for the benefit of society.

text1: Healthcare costs more than Education.
text2: The right to education is a similar human right which is accepted and functioning. It is similar in that it requires a functioning economy, trained paid professionals, and has a private alternative.

text1: Healthcare costs more than Education.
text2: Cost should not decide what is a right, but only cause a limit to the extent a right can be upheld.

text1: Education is limited by age and level, while healthcare cannot be similarly limited.
text2: The right to education is a similar human right which is accepted and functioning. It is similar in that it requires a functioning economy, trained paid professionals, and has a private alternative.

text1: Education is limited by age and level, while healthcare cannot be similarly limited.
text2: Healthcare can also be limited for elective procedures and/or limited to crucial non-elective procedures.

text1: Education is limited by age and level, while healthcare cannot be similarly limited.
text2: Human rights have limitations. For example, the right to life can be limited in cases of self-defense, and the right to freedom of speech can be limited in cases of hate speech or breaching legally binding agreements.

text1: The right to food does not imply that governments have an obligation to hand out free food to everyone who wants it, or a right to be fed. This is not a human right in the same way that health care is suggested to become a human right.
text2: The right to food, and the right to housing, are internationally defined and accepted, but require labor, money, and effort.

text1: The right to food does not imply that governments have an obligation to hand out free food to everyone who wants it, or a right to be fed. This is not a human right in the same way that health care is suggested to become a human right.
text2: The ICESCR says "the right to adequate food is realised when every man, woman and child, alone or in community with others, have the physical and economic access at all times to adequate food or means for its procurement."

text1: Voting, in most jurisdictions, is optional.
text2: The right to vote requires the state to offer every voter suitable means and locations to vote, including election officials and judges.

text1: Not all nations hold elections.
text2: The right to vote requires the state to offer every voter suitable means and locations to vote, including election officials and judges.

text1: The right to representation is triggered only when the state charges you in criminal court, therefore it exists with constraints unlike publicly provisioned health care.
text2: The state provides citizens with free counsel in order to uphold their right to a fair trial.

text1: The right to representation is triggered only when the state charges you in criminal court, therefore it exists with constraints unlike publicly provisioned health care.
text2: Access to health care by a public practitioner can also be placed within reasonable constraints.

text1: These rights are different, they are positive not negative, and are economic, social, and cultural.
text2: Several other human rights rely on the labor of others, and the resources of the state, to be upheld.

text1: These rights are different, they are positive not negative, and are economic, social, and cultural.
text2: The UN argues that the enjoyment of all human rights is interlinked so categories of rights such as “civil and political rights” or “economic, social and cultural rights” make little sense.

text1: These rights are different, they are positive not negative, and are economic, social, and cultural.
text2: Three generations of human rights includes these rights as human rights (second and third generations).

text1: Health care, as a human right, can be argued to be similarly interlinked to other fundamental human rights, such as the right to life.
text2: The UN argues that the enjoyment of all human rights is interlinked so categories of rights such as “civil and political rights” or “economic, social and cultural rights” make little sense.

text1: These also shouldn't be considered rights. Rights should not impose any obligation on others, they should only require non-interference.
text2: Several other human rights rely on the labor of others, and the resources of the state, to be upheld.

text1: The state's allocation of resources to specific initiatives cannot be used as a proxy to determine whether something is a human right.
text2: Several other human rights rely on the labor of others, and the resources of the state, to be upheld.

text1: The lack of financial consequences does not equate to the absence of physical repercussions.
text2: Free healthcare may lead to neglect of personal health due to lack of financial consequences, resulting in a burden on the government funding the care.

text1: No one would purposely hurt themselves because they could get healthcare for free.
text2: Free healthcare may lead to neglect of personal health due to lack of financial consequences, resulting in a burden on the government funding the care.

text1: Most people are naturally deterred from engaging in unhealthy or risky behavior due to a fear of injury or death.
text2: If treated as a civil right, people won't take responsibility for unhealthy behaviors.

text1: Most people are naturally deterred from engaging in unhealthy or risky behavior due to a fear of injury or death.
text2: A lack of free health care may enhance a person's natural aversion to risky behavior.

text1: Countries can create incentives that nudge people towards better life choices.
text2: If treated as a civil right, people won't take responsibility for unhealthy behaviors.

text1: Countries can create incentives that nudge people towards better life choices.
text2: The goal to restrict people from engaging in any behavior that might jeopardize their health is unrealistic.

text1: It cannot be stated with certainty that unhealthy habits such as smoking wholly cause a given disease.
text2: Individual choices, like smoking, raise the risk of future illnesses and drive up healthcare expenses.

text1: It cannot be stated with certainty that unhealthy habits such as smoking wholly cause a given disease.
text2: While it may be difficult to attribute a particular disease entirely to smoking, there is a strong correlation between smoking and various health conditions, such as lung cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and heart disease.

text1: It cannot be stated with certainty that unhealthy habits such as smoking wholly cause a given disease.
text2: The risk of developing smoking-related diseases decreases after quitting smoking, supporting the link between smoking and disease.

text1: Individual choices, such as smoking, already come at a greater cost to people due to increased taxation by the state.
text2: Individual choices, like smoking, raise the risk of future illnesses and drive up healthcare expenses.

text1: Individual choices, such as smoking, already come at a greater cost to people due to increased taxation by the state.
text2: The tax burden of universal healthcare is likely to be the same for every citizen, regardless of their smoking habits.

text1: People are often coerced into adopting unhealthy habits such as smoking due to aggressive marketing.
text2: Individual choices, like smoking, raise the risk of future illnesses and drive up healthcare expenses.

text1: People are often coerced into adopting unhealthy habits such as smoking due to aggressive marketing.
text2: It is not the government's responsibility to regulate or monitor people's vulnerability to drug use through persuasive advertisements.

text1: People are often coerced into adopting unhealthy habits such as smoking due to aggressive marketing.
text2: Many countries around the world have complete or partial bans on tobacco advertising.

text1: Healthcare should be apportioned by need rather than each person receiving the same amount.
text2: Statistically, 1% of the population consistently uses up to 20% of the total health care expenditure in the US, and 5% uses almost 50%.

text1: If these 1% or 5% have much more serious diseases than the rest, it wouldn't be fair not to give them the support they need.
text2: Statistically, 1% of the population consistently uses up to 20% of the total health care expenditure in the US, and 5% uses almost 50%.

text1: Accepted human rights entitle people to make claims on the resources of others, it just requires prudence in distributing resources, and not, a justification to discard the right.
text2: Unhealthy individuals tend to utilize a disproportionately large share of healthcare resources.

text1: Accepted human rights entitle people to make claims on the resources of others, it just requires prudence in distributing resources, and not, a justification to discard the right.
text2: Some human rights are negative rights, meaning that they only require that other people don't negate them.

text1: All people will need health care at some point in their lives, and whatever they pay for it today is something they will benefit from in the future.
text2: Unhealthy individuals tend to utilize a disproportionately large share of healthcare resources.

text1: Modern societies require citizens to pay for the consequences of others' actions, from funding law enforcement and correctional facilities to financing litter collection.
text2: Other individuals' poor lifestyle choices force healthy people to bear the costs.

text1: Modern societies require citizens to pay for the consequences of others' actions, from funding law enforcement and correctional facilities to financing litter collection.
text2: Situations where an individual benefits at the disproportionate cost of society, especially when it's an intentional decision, should be minimized.

text1: Modern societies require citizens to pay for the consequences of others' actions, from funding law enforcement and correctional facilities to financing litter collection.
text2: Whether something exists or how widespread its practice is at any given point in time is not an indication of its social utility.

text1: Societies trade individual freedoms for security; policing is a traded freedom, and so should be healthcare.
text2: Situations where an individual benefits at the disproportionate cost of society, especially when it's an intentional decision, should be minimized.

text1: Costs borne by individuals for sustaining health care can be minimized.
text2: Situations where an individual benefits at the disproportionate cost of society, especially when it's an intentional decision, should be minimized.

text1: Society is responsible for their choices even if they are poor ones.
text2: Whether something exists or how widespread its practice is at any given point in time is not an indication of its social utility.

text1: There are compounding factors that influence a persons health that are independent of choice.
text2: Other individuals' poor lifestyle choices force healthy people to bear the costs.

text1: There are compounding factors that influence a persons health that are independent of choice.
text2: Individuals have a responsibility to seek out accurate information and make informed decisions about their health.

text1: There are compounding factors that influence a persons health that are independent of choice.
text2: Many health conditions, such as heat disease and diabetes, can be managed or even prevented through lifestyle choices and medical interventions.

text1: There are compounding factors that influence a persons health that are independent of choice.
text2: People are still responsible for making choices on how to manage the preexisting health conditions and what types of treatments to pursue.

text1: Food is a basic human necessity and a human right, and farmers are similarly expected to provide for the rest of humanity.
text2: Health care, if considered a human right, forces others in society to bear costs they did not cause.

text1: Food is a basic human necessity and a human right, and farmers are similarly expected to provide for the rest of humanity.
text2: Unlike healthcare, sourcing, obtaining, and preparing food can be done independently, without relying on others.

text1: Food is a basic human necessity and a human right, and farmers are similarly expected to provide for the rest of humanity.
text2: The US has opposed international calls to consider food as a human right.

text1: The USA is an outlier as it refuses to ratify many otherwise-globally-accepted treaties such as the Conventaion against Torture, the Arms Trade Treaty, Convention on the Rights of the Child, Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, and even the treaty on treaties.
text2: The US has opposed international calls to consider food as a human right.

text1: Citizens bear the cost of health care through taxation, which is a fair payment in exchange for the government's provision of services.
text2: Health care, if considered a human right, forces others in society to bear costs they did not cause.

text1: Citizens bear the cost of health care through taxation, which is a fair payment in exchange for the government's provision of services.
text2: Being unable to opt out of paying taxes and not having a say in how they are allocated equals compulsion to support something unwanted.

text1: Citizens bear the cost of health care through taxation, which is a fair payment in exchange for the government's provision of services.
text2: Healthcare professionals also bear the cost of health care as a human right through a loss in wage.

text1: A person can have a say in how taxes are spent by voting for a representative who aligns with their desired allocation of funds.
text2: Being unable to opt out of paying taxes and not having a say in how they are allocated equals compulsion to support something unwanted.

text1: A person can have a say in how taxes are spent by voting for a representative who aligns with their desired allocation of funds.
text2: Majority rule, making decisions based on preferences of the majority, may devolve into mob rule and not adequately protect minority rights.

text1: If doctors start exiting the healthcare market, the government is likely to incentivize them to stay within the system to maintain supply.
text2: Healthcare professionals also bear the cost of health care as a human right through a loss in wage.

text1: If doctors start exiting the healthcare market, the government is likely to incentivize them to stay within the system to maintain supply.
text2: Doctors often relocate abroad to access higher salaries in the private market.

text1: The government similarly sustains a network of professionals and maintains an extensive infrastructure to ensure the people's right to a fair trial.
text2: More than 90% of the cases never get to a jury, and the prosecutors have enormous leeway in selecting which transgressions they will bring to trial.

text1: This doesn't contradict the fact that every defendant has the right to an attorney, state-funded if necessary.
text2: More than 90% of the cases never get to a jury, and the prosecutors have enormous leeway in selecting which transgressions they will bring to trial.

text1: Passion often drives career choices, not just money; people are motivated by their love for the work, and not necessarily salaries.
text2: Healthcare professionals also bear the cost of health care as a human right through a loss in wage.

text1: Widespread provision of health care in a society improves its economy.
text2: Declaring healthcare as a human right is economically unfeasible.

text1: Widespread provision of health care in a society improves its economy.
text2: An improved economy is not a characteristic of a human right.

text1: Widespread provision of health care in a society improves its economy.
text2: Universal health care would be incredibly costly and therefore detrimental to the economy.

text1: Healthcare systems that are not universal are inefficient, and create loss for an economy.
text2: Government provision of health care is likely to create a very inefficient system.

text1: Healthcare systems that are not universal are inefficient, and create loss for an economy.
text2: Providing universal health care will harm the healthcare industry.

text1: Healthcare systems that are not universal are inefficient, and create loss for an economy.
text2: Increasing healthcare availability and reducing costs are important goals, and declaring health care as a human right may not achieve them.

text1: Non-universal healthcare systems often have high administrative costs, as insurance companies and healthcare providers negotiate prices and coverage.
text2: Government bureaucracies can also generate excessive administrative costs through inefficient management.

text1: Non-universal healthcare systems often have high administrative costs, as insurance companies and healthcare providers negotiate prices and coverage.
text2: Insurance companies already operate on very thin margins, therefore to important that they have negotiating power in order remain competitive.

text1: Without a universal healthcare system, patients lack the bargaining power to negotiate lower prices for medical procedures and treatments, which can lead to high costs for both patients and the healthcare system.
text2: Government regulation controlling for exorbitant pricing can exist even in the absence of a universal healthcare system.

text1: In the USA, one of the wealthiest nations in the world, citizens spend more per capita on healthcare than citizens of countries with socialized healthcare.
text2: Government bureaucracy complicates healthcare and raises costs, while the free market provides better healthcare to more people.

text1: Unregulated for-profit healthcare corporations overprice insulin, making it unaffordable for those who need it.
text2: Government bureaucracy complicates healthcare and raises costs, while the free market provides better healthcare to more people.

text1: Private providers can also be corrupt by billing patients or the state fraudulently.
text2: Public healthcare systems are likely to be corrupt.

text1: Public healthcare can operate without corruption, and there is no proven link between corruption levels and healthcare outcomes across countries.
text2: Public healthcare systems are likely to be corrupt.

text1: Direct healthcare financing makes health insurance optional, which prioritizes protecting the general population's health over increased health insurance costs.
text2: State provision or financing of healthcare may facilitate corruption and artificially inflate health insurance costs.

text1: US healthcare is the world's most expensive, while government-funded systems in Europe offer lower costs and universal access.
text2: State provision or financing of healthcare may facilitate corruption and artificially inflate health insurance costs.

text1: A healthcare system that does not discriminate clients based on their ability to pay is more efficient in improving a country's overall health outcomes.
text2: Government provision of health care is likely to create a very inefficient system.

text1: A private health care sector can also be inefficient due to variances in pricing.
text2: Government provision of health care is likely to create a very inefficient system.

text1: Medical professionals often belong to the highest income bracket in their nation, even when the healthcare system is publicly run.
text2: Medical professionals' income is likely to decline within a publicly run healthcare system.

text1: Most investment into healthcare is publicly funded, this is unlikely to change.
text2: Innovation within the healthcare industry is likely to reduce.

text1: A universal healthcare system will allow for better coordination of healthcare services, reducing waste and inefficiency.
text2: Providing universal health care will harm the healthcare industry.

text1: A universal healthcare system simplifies decision-making for the consumer.
text2: Providing universal health care will harm the healthcare industry.

text1: A universal healthcare system simplifies decision-making for the consumer.
text2: Governments have started to require private providers to publish complete price-lists, thereby increasing the access to information for consumers.

text1: Studies and international health organisations agree that healthcare drives economic growth.
text2: The link between health care and economic growth is complex and multifaceted, and may not always be straightforward.

text1: Studies and international health organisations agree that healthcare drives economic growth.
text2: While health care may drive economic growth overall, it may not necessarily benefit all segments of society equally, and may exacerbate existing inequalities in access to health care and economic opportunities.

text1: Human rights and a positive economy are directly correlated, implying that a positive economy is not just a characteristic, but a requirement for the existence of human rights.
text2: An improved economy is not a characteristic of a human right.

text1: The US health care cost has been growing independent of universal coverage, and recently accounted for nearly 20% of the GDP expenditure.
text2: Universal healthcare requires a large amount of funding to cover the costs of providing healthcare to every citizen, regardless of their ability to pay.

text1: Insurance companies often negotiate lower prices than the published chargemaster rates.
text2: The primary driver of healthcare cost is insurance companies, which can be contained in a publicly run healthcare system.

text1: Insurance companies are known to overcharge customers even when operating within universal healthcare systems.
text2: The primary driver of healthcare cost is insurance companies, which can be contained in a publicly run healthcare system.

text1: Patents in the pharmaceutical industry significantly contribute to healthcare costs by driving up drug prices.
text2: The primary driver of healthcare cost is insurance companies, which can be contained in a publicly run healthcare system.

text1: The lack of a universal health care is significantly more expensive and puts an even heavier burden on individuals than the taxes that would be used to supply everyone with healthcare.
text2: Universal healthcare is too expensive.

text1: The lack of a universal health care is significantly more expensive and puts an even heavier burden on individuals than the taxes that would be used to supply everyone with healthcare.
text2: Individuals' poor personal decisions, such as poor dental hygiene and consumption of sugary foods, can outweigh the impact of government-funded healthcare.

text1: The combined economic impact of ill-health currently sits at a £77.5 billion a year for the UK economy.
text2: This is lower than the UK's health care budget, of £145 billion.

text1: Universal healthcare can be affordable through cost control measures, which some countries have implemented.
text2: Universal healthcare is too expensive.

text1: Universal healthcare can be affordable through cost control measures, which some countries have implemented.
text2: Many cost-control strategies within public healthcare systems have led to wage cuts.

text1: Many countries provide universal healthcare, showing that any detrimental economic effects are not substantial.
text2: Universal health care would be incredibly costly and therefore detrimental to the economy.

text1: Many countries provide universal healthcare, showing that any detrimental economic effects are not substantial.
text2: The cost forecast for universal health coverage in California was more than the state's entire budget.
